learning_outcomes.description: Use thermodynamics concepts to reason about the behaviour of macroscopic properties of physical systems. In particular, you should develop an appreciation of the power of thermodynamics to understand a diverse range of systems relevant to physics, chemistry, biology, engineering, and earth sciences.

Apply the laws of thermodynamics to physical, chemical and engineering applications, deriving relationships between macroscopic quantities and making quantitative predictions of thermodynamic behaviour. You should get a feel for order of magnitude estimates of thermodynamic quantities in typical systems and be able to perform 'back of the envelope' calculations, in addition to well-reasoned analytic and computational work.
Ability to use a computer to investigate thermodynamic phenomena and simulate complex processes
Investigate thermodynamic phenomena experimentally, applying laboratory skills and error analysis to test theoretical predictions
Develop report writing and communication skills

assessments.assessment_title: In-class tests on Applied Class problems
assessments.due_date: The tests will occur in Weeks 2-11 and 13, during your allocated Applied Class contact hour.
assessments.task_description: Students will be required to answer quick (often multiple choice) quiz-like test questions related to your applied class problems from previous week. The tests will occur in Weeks 2-11 and 13, during your allocated Applied Class contact hour. The test questions must be solved under exam conditions (with no access to the Internet). They will be marked for correctness and based on the student's ability to show their understanding of the material presented in the relevant section of the course. Out of 11 such tests, only 5 are required to attain the maximum 15% weight for this assessment component. If you complete more than 5 tests, only 5 best marks will be counted.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Your answers to the test questions must be handed in to the casual academic in hard copy, on supplied A4 papers, during the Applied Class.

learning_activities.topic:
Computer programming

Physics is done computationally as much as by experimental or analytic work. Computational physics is embedded in this course not only in applied class problem sets and labs, but also in a dedicated Computational Physics project. The Computational Physics project gives you an opportunity to program a model of a physical system and investigate its properties. To cover the basics of Computational Physics, and for those with little computational or programming experience, there will be introductory sessions during laboratory classes in week 2, as well as two dedicated lectures in Week 9.

You can obtain further assistance with the computational work during Applied Classes, by asking questions on Ed discussion board or using AI within UQ guidelines.

learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

The lectures will focus on processing the knowledge obtained from the assigned readings. We will make use of concept questions (please install PointSolutions app on your phone) and peer discussion to ensure students gain a deep conceptual understanding of thermodynamics.

learning_activities.topic:
Applied Classes

Solving problems is an essential part of *doing* physics, rather than just learning *about* physics. This activity is also the ultimate test of your physics understanding. We have assembled a comprehensive set of problems in thermodynamics, and it is essential that you practice solving these problems every week.

The Applied Classes will provide training for solving thermodynamics problems.

Note that the final exam questions will be similar in style to Applied Class problems and in-class tests.

learning_activities.topic:
Laboratory

There will be 5 lab (prac) sessions during semester. During the first Introductory Lab session (in Week 1), students will be rostered in pairs or small groups to work on two assigned experiments. This session will include report writing instructions and data analysis training. Students attend lab sessions on only one day of the week.

Following the Introductory Lab session, students will complete two laboratory experiments (each conducted over two sessions) during semester and submit two laboratory written reports. The laboratory activities will help you to develop your skills at physical concepts, data analysis, and communicating the results. Further instructions about the format of the reports will be provided on Blackboard.
